quotedObject.fullText:
Outer hair cells are found only in mammals.  Do you know how they relate to melanin?  

Schematic overview of melanin‚Äêcontaining cells in the mammalian inner ear. Melanin‚Äêcontaining cells (melanocytes, melanophages, and perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes cells; all in green) are present in the vestibular organs (U, S, and A), the cochlea (C), and the endolymphatic sac (ES). A: Cross‚Äêsection of the ampulla of a semicircular canal (SSC). Subepithelial melanocytes (1) are present underneath the dark cell epithelium (red). Also, perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes (2) and subepithelial melanophages (3) are present in the subepithelial connective tissue. Subepithelial melanocytes are also associated with the dark cell epithelium in the area of the ampullar roof that connects to the opening of the utricle (4). In the semicircular canal proper (not shown), subepithelial melanocytes are present within the loosely arranged connective tissue of the periotic (perilymphatic) spaces. U: Cross‚Äêsection of the utricle. Subepithelial melanocytes (1) are associated with the dark cell epithelium (red). Perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes (2) and subepithelial melanophages (3) are present in the subepithelial connective tissue as well as perineural melanocytes (4) surrounding the nerve fibers. Subepithelial melanocytes are also associated with the dark cell epithelium in the utricular roof (5). S: Cross‚Äêsection of the saccule. Perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes (1) are present in the subepithelial connective tissue. C: Cross‚Äêsection of a quarter turn of the cochlea. In the lateral wall, intermediate cells, and perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes are present in the stria vascularis (1). In the spiral ligament, perivascular melanocytes are mainly located in the region superior and inferior to the stria vascularis (2). In the modiolus, perivascular (3) and perineural (4) melanocytes are present. Additionally, melanocytes are interspersed among the mesothelial cells in the modiolar wall facing the scala tympani (5) and scala vestibuli (6). Melanocytes are also present between the basement membrane and mesothelial cells of the tympanic covering layer of the osseous spiral lamina and basilar membrane (7), and on the mesothelial side of the basement membrane of the Reissner's membrane (8)

quotedObject.fullText:
Sunlight, Dopamine, Neuromelanin, and the Substantia Nigra

Exposure to full-spectrum sunlight stimulates the production of neuromelanin in the substantia nigra.

This neuromelanin in the midbrain protects the dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra from oxidative damage by removing free radicals.

Additionally, the substantia nigra plays a crucial role in motor control, housing dopamine neurons that are essential for movement and even time perception.

All About the Substantia Nigra
The substantia nigra, a dark streak in the midbrain's uncolored tissue, is named from Latin, "black substance."

There are two substantiae nigrae, one on each side of the midline of the midbrain.

These two distinct regions are the substantia nigra pars compacta and the substantia nigra pars reticulata. 

The substantia nigra gets its dark coloring from the large number of dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, as they express high levels of a dark pigment called neuromelanin. 

In fact, most of the dopamine-producing neurons of the brain are found in the substantia nigra or an adjacent area called the ventral tegmental area. 

The dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra are primarily found in the substantia nigra pars compacta, as the substantia nigra pars reticulata is more heavily populated with GABA neurons.

Significance of Substantia Nigra in Motor Control 
The substantia nigra is part of a brain region called the basal ganglia. 

It has dopamine neurons that connect to other parts of the basal ganglia, like the caudate and putamen (which are together known as the striatum).

These dopamine neurons make up a large bundle of fibers called the nigrostriatal pathway. 

The nigrostriatal pathway is one of the major dopamine pathways in the brain and is extremely important in the facilitation of movement. 

The GABA neurons of the substantia nigra pars reticulata also play important roles in movement, and thus movement is one of the main functions of the substantia nigra.

Neuromelanin is the darkest pigment found in humans.

"Full-spectrum sunlight stimulates the synthesis of neuromelanin in the midbrain, just as it stimulates the synthesis of melanin in the skin (tan)." - @DrJackKruse 
 
Neuromelanin is also a pigment with strong iron-chelating properties. 

The conversion of dopamine to neuromelanin is prompted by iron because the chelator desferrioxamine is able to block neuromelanin synthesis. 

Parkinson's disease is characterized by pronounced, MRI-detectable neuromelanin loss and low Vitamin D levels/

Role of Light in Neuromelanin Production (Study)
Rats raised in dim light-dark cycles showed few neurons containing neuromelanin. 

When exposed to continuous bright light at around 436.6 nanometers, rats showed increased neuromelanin production with more neurons containing it.

This effect was even more pronounced in rats raised entirely in continuous bright light for three months.

Outer hair cells are found only in mammals.  Do you know how they relate to melanin?  

Schematic overview of melanin‚Äêcontaining cells in the mammalian inner ear. Melanin‚Äêcontaining cells (melanocytes, melanophages, and perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes cells; all in green) are present in the vestibular organs (U, S, and A), the cochlea (C), and the endolymphatic sac (ES). A: Cross‚Äêsection of the ampulla of a semicircular canal (SSC). Subepithelial melanocytes (1) are present underneath the dark cell epithelium (red). Also, perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes (2) and subepithelial melanophages (3) are present in the subepithelial connective tissue. Subepithelial melanocytes are also associated with the dark cell epithelium in the area of the ampullar roof that connects to the opening of the utricle (4). In the semicircular canal proper (not shown), subepithelial melanocytes are present within the loosely arranged connective tissue of the periotic (perilymphatic) spaces. U: Cross‚Äêsection of the utricle. Subepithelial melanocytes (1) are associated with the dark cell epithelium (red). Perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes (2) and subepithelial melanophages (3) are present in the subepithelial connective tissue as well as perineural melanocytes (4) surrounding the nerve fibers. Subepithelial melanocytes are also associated with the dark cell epithelium in the utricular roof (5). S: Cross‚Äêsection of the saccule. Perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes (1) are present in the subepithelial connective tissue. C: Cross‚Äêsection of a quarter turn of the cochlea. In the lateral wall, intermediate cells, and perivascular‚Äêresident macrophage‚Äêlike melanocytes are present in the stria vascularis (1). In the spiral ligament, perivascular melanocytes are mainly located in the region superior and inferior to the stria vascularis (2). In the modiolus, perivascular (3) and perineural (4) melanocytes are present. Additionally, melanocytes are interspersed among the mesothelial cells in the modiolar wall facing the scala tympani (5) and scala vestibuli (6). Melanocytes are also present between the basement membrane and mesothelial cells of the tympanic covering layer of the osseous spiral lamina and basilar membrane (7), and on the mesothelial side of the basement membrane of the Reissner's membrane (8)

quotedObject.fullText:
Brown eyes üëÅ

Melanocytes in dark-colored eyes have a high quantity of melanin, which is more protective than that in light-colored eyes, consistent with the higher incidence of uveal melanoma in the light-colored eye.

It is important to note that the number of melanocytes in the iris does not differ per iris colour group (light, intermediate or dark iris colour).  As there is no difference in the number of melanocytes, the difference in iris colour is determined by the melanosome composition and structure of the melanocytes in the stroma.

There are two different types of melanin: eumelanin and pheomelanin. The pigment epithelium mainly contains eumelanin. The main determinants of iris colour are the amount of eumelanin and the ratio of eumelanin to pheomelanin.

The antioxidant properties of melanin are related to the type of melanin‚Äîthe greater the ratio of eumelanin to pheomelanin, the more antioxidative the pigment. 

Darker eyes have a greater eumelanin:pheomelanin ratio.

"We hypothesize that damage from environmental factors or age-related factors create more DNA damage in melanocytes that contain mainly pheomelanin than in melanocytes with mainly eumelanin."
